metadata.title: Solidification acceleration in a triplex-tube latent heat thermal energy storage system using V-shaped fin and nano-enhanced phase change material

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Thermal Engineering
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/apthermeng
Solidification acceleration in a triplex-tube latent heat thermal energy storage system using V-shaped fin and nano-enhanced phase change material
M. Alizadeha, Kh. Hosseinzadeha, M.H. Shahavib, D.D. Ganjia
a Department of Mechanical Engineering, Babol Noushirvani University of Technology, Babol, Iran b Faculty of Engineering Modern Technologies, Amol University of Special Modern Technologies (AUSMT), Amol, Iran
H I G H L I G H T S
• Solidification process of PCM and NEPCM in the triplex-tube LHTESS are studied. • Effect of V-shaped fin on the solidification acceleration is investigated. • Geometric parameters of V-shaped fin are optimized using RSM. • FEM is used to simulate the solidification process. • V-shaped fin causes faster solidification process than nanoparticle dispersion.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Solidification Triplex-tube LHTESS NEPCM V-shaped fin RSM
A B S T R A C T
This study deals with solidification expedition of Phase Change Material (PCM) in a triplex-tube Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage System (LHTESS) by employing V-shaped fins and nanoparticles as enhancement approaches. The application of such systems is to balance the energy supply and requirement. Both approaches are used to compensate for the insignificant thermal conductivity of pure Phase Change Material and preventing the solidification process from weakening. In first enhancement approach, Response Surface Method (RSM) is used to optimize the geometric parameters of V-shaped fins to achieve best fin arrangement. The objective function of fin optimization is minimizing the Full Solidification Time (FST) to achieve the accelerated phase change process. In the second approach, SWCNT nanoparticles are dispersed to the water as Phase Change Material, and Nano-Enhanced Phase Change Material (NEPCM) is formed. Both approaches are performed separately and their results are compared. The simulation of solidification process is carried out utilizing Standard Galerkin Finite Element Method (SGFEM) along with adaptive grid refinement strategy. Results exhibited that using V-shaped fin in the system causes higher acceleration to the procedure, in comparison with nanoparticles dispersion.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, the increasing interest to reduce energy emission and also some defects of fossil fuels such as resource limitation and environmental impacts have caused the global society to look towards renewable energy. The purpose of using this kind of energy is to store the thermal energy so that the existing break between the energy stores and energy requirements is overcome. Energy storage is divided to several categories such as: sensible heat, latent heat and chemical energy storage. Numerous researches are conducted on (LHTESS) due to its capacity to save massive amount of energy with a little increase in
temperature. Moreover, PCM with high latent heat of fusion can be employed in these systems to enhance their efficiency. Many applications such as: removing heat from electronic tools [1,2], removing heat from mobile devices [3] and using heat pipes for cooling [4] benefit from PCMs.
During past decades, numerous researchers have widely focused on using PCM in their researches due to its high storage capability. For example, Panchabikesan et al. [5] numerically studied the impact of thermal conductivity on solidification process of RT82 as PCM within a LHTESS. Results revealed that augmenting the thermal conductivity of used PCM leads to decrease the solidification time for all ranges of fluid

velocity. Jmal and Baccar [6] examined the solidification procedure of a rectangular PCM adjacent to a cold air flow considering natural convection. The authors compared two different PCMs from the sight of solidification time. Results depicted that by using RT72 paraffin as PCM, 55% of solidification process completes after 90min, but this percent will change to 40% for C18 paraffin. An analytical and numeric investigation on solidification procedure of PCM inside an enclosure was performed by Taghilou and Talati [7]. The comparison between analytical and numerical results showed an excellent agreement in top region from the sight of temperature distribution. But, a slight difference was reported in the bottom region. Zarajabad and Ahmadi [8] numerically evaluated the influence of PCM volume on performance of the LHTESS. The authors employed PCM with different thicknesses between 0.5 cm and 6 cm in their simulation. Results depicted that considering the 3 cm PCM results in best performance from the sight of improving the discharging time. Sahan and Paksoy [9] used novel shapeable PCM composites in a TESS. Less volume, no leakage and considerable storage capacity were reported as some advantages of such system. Mahdi and Nsofor [10] analyzed the effect of cascade metal foam as PCM on thermal performance of a LHTESS. Results depicted that augmenting the cascade number affects the phase change procedure considerably so that the solidification or melting time is reduced.
Beside the high storage capacity of PCM, its thermal conductivity is considerably low which weakens the heat transfer processes. This defect can be fixed by different improvement approaches. One of these approaches is to disperse nanoparticles to the pure PCM and making Nano-Enhanced PCM (NEPCM). Numerous studied have been carried on using NEPCM in the LHTESS. Recently, Alizadeh et al. [11] analyzed the solidification process within a LHTESS with Koch snowflake cross section by using hybrid nanoparticles enhanced PCM. Results depicted that increasing the nanoparticles shape factor causes higher solid fraction in the system which accelerates the solidification process. Singh et al. [12] studied the impact of Graphene nano plates (GNP) on solidification procedure in a fin- assisted TESS. They concluded that dispersing 5% GNP to the pure PCM causes the solidification time to be decreased by about 49%. A numerical investigation based on finite volume method on solidification process of NEPCM in a rectangular LHTESS was performed by Elbahjaoui an El Qarnia [13]. They demonstrated that by making NEPCM, the system efficiency is increased from the sight of reducing the discharging time. Mahdi and Nsofor et al. [14] evaluated the effect of alumina nanoparticles on solidification of PCM in the triplex-tube heat exchanger. Results showed that adding alumina nanoparticles with volume concentration of 3–8% to pure PCM leads to reduce the solidification time between 8% and 20%. Gorzin et al. [15] reviewed the reduction of solidification time by using NEPCM. Results illustrated that a reduction of 15% is obtained in solidification time by augmenting the nanoparticle volume fraction to 4%.
Lohrasbi et al. [16] dispersed Cu nanoparticles into the PCM to expedite the solidification process in a LHTESS. They indicated that a reduction of 8.8% and 16% will take place in solidification time using Cu nanoparticles with 2.5% and 5% volume fractions, respectively. It is noteworthy that the LHTESS containing NEPCM has been investigated by many other researchers [17–24].
As mentioned before, adding nanoparticles is one technique to compensate the weak thermal conductivity of PCMs. Employing extended surfaces is another technique to improve the heat transfer due to increased heat transfer area. The effect of fins with different shapes has been analyzed in various applications. Ahmad et al. [25] analyzed the influence of fin thickness variation on the efficiency of a heat exchanger. Results reported an increase of about 15.09% in the rate of heat transfer, as compared to triangular fins. Hosseinzadeh et al. [26] applied tree-shaped fins to the LHTESS to hasten the solidification in the system. They revealed that raising the fin bifurcation angle enhances the solidification rate in the process. Mahdi and Nsofor [27] reviewed the influence of nanoparticle-fin combination on the efficiency of a triplex-tube LHTESS. The authors attached eight equal longitudinal fins to external surface of inner tube and also internal surface of the middle tube. It was observed that the triplex-tube LHTESS experiences its best performance when longitudinal fins are employed alone. Alizadeh et al. [28] investigated the application of Y-shaped fins in solidification of PCM in the LHTESS. Results showed the procedure acceleration by raising the fin length and bifurcation angle. The effect of fins with variable thickness on solidification of PCM in the LHTESS was reported by Hosseinzadeh et al. [29]. Authors depicted that by varying the thickness of fins, the solidification time reduces by 9.93% in comparison with longitudinal fins.
As mentioned before, using conductive fins in LHTESS leads to desirable heat transfer and solidification rates. Also, by optimizing the fin arrangement in such systems, the best performance can be achieved. Therefore, numerous studies have been carried on fin optimization in LHTESS. Recently, Sheikholeslami et al. [30] optimized the snowflakeshaped fin in a LHTESS using RSM to expedite the procedure. Results showed that adding fin with any shapes results in a higher solidification rate, as compared to nanoparticle dispersion. Bhagat et al. [31] evaluated the performance of a LHTESS by optimizing the fin geometric parameters such as the fin number, the fin thickness and the fin height. Results showed that the LHTESS efficiency is considerably affected by the fin thickness and the fin number. A study on fin arrangement optimization in a thermal storage system was done by Augspurger et al. [32]. They demonstrated that the container geometry and salt to aluminum ratio are known as the key factors, while the effect of parameters such as: fin number, fin thickness and the aluminum divisions on the system performance can be ignored.

triplex-tube LHTESS by employing V-shaped fins on middle tube and also dispersion of nanoparticles into the pure PCM. Due to both sides solidifying approach in the annulus which accelerates the process, the triplex-tube configuration is employed. The V-shaped fin arrangement is optimized to obtain the most accelerated process. In this optimization, obtaining minimum FST is regarded as the objective function. In order to simulate the solidification process, the SGFEM along with adaptive grid refinement strategy is employed. Finally, the abovementioned enhancement approaches are compared from the sight of minimizing the FST. Unlike the previous studies, the efficiency of nanoparticle dispersion in PCM, adding fin with V-shaped structures and triplex-tube configuration on LHTESS performance have been studied from the viewpoint of either discharging rate or maximum energy storage capacity. The abovementioned points are proposed as the novelties of present work.

sections.heading: 2. Problem description
sections.text:
Fig. 1 represents the two-dimensional schematic and boundary conditions. This figure shows the cross-section of V-shaped fin assisted triplex-tube LHTESS in the physical model. The Heat Transfer Fluid (HTF) fills the internal and external tubes of the triplex-tube LHTESS and the PCM is solidified in the middle tube of the system. The temperature of the inner and the middle tubes of triplex-tube LHTESS is assumed to be 240 K, which is constant during the process. Moreover, the pure PCM fills the middle tube with the primary temperature of 278 K. The initial solid fraction of PCM area is assumed to be equal to
0.0, because the PCM is in liquid phase at the start of the process. Also, the solid fraction equal to 1 is enforced for the fin region. Moreover, Vshaped fin is added to the inner surface of the middle tube to augment the Thermal Penetration Depth (TPD) in regions containing PCM. The internal and external diameters of the triplex-tube LHTESS are 20 and 80mm, respectively. Firstly, a two-dimensional simulation is performed using Finite Element Method to evaluate the performance of V-shaped fin within the triplex-tube LHTESS. Also, by using RSM, the geometric parameters of V-shaped fin are optimized to achieve the best fin arrangement. Secondly, SWCNT nanoparticles with three different volume fractions are dispersed into the pure PCM and the results are compared with the optimized V-shaped fin assisted LHTESS from the sight of solidification rate. The geometric parameters of V-shaped fin which are used in the optimization procedure are presented in Table 1 with their ranges (see Fig. 2).
In Table 2, the PCM thermophysical properties, SWCNT nanoparticles and fin material are listed. As phase change occurs in the solidification procedure, the variation of thermophysical properties during the process is considered, in this simulation. Therefore, the
thermophysical properties of PCM are presented for both phases. In this investigation, a time-step of × −2 10 (s)5 is considered due to the dependency of the solidification procedure to time in the triplex-tube LHTESS.
According to abovementioned points, following assumptions are assigned for simulating the solidification procedure in the V-shaped fin assisted triplex-tube LHTESS:
– A two-dimensional simulation in Cartesian coordinates is
performed. – An unsteady simulation is performed for the solidification procedure in the V-shaped fin assisted triplex-tube LHTESS. – The influence of free convection on solidification process is ignored and the conduction is the predominant mechanism for the heat transfer. – The variation of thermophysical properties of PCM is taken into account, because phase change is involved in this process. – Constant thermophysical properties are considered for PCM and NEPCM in each phase.

sections.heading: 3. Numerical procedure and validation
sections.text:
In present study, the simulation of solidification process is carried out using SGFEM with the aid of FlexPDE 5.0.18 software. In order to solve the phase change procedure, cubic interpolation is applied over triangles. In the problems with triangle grid, the calculations are performed on the corner of cells which is called as node. In this method, the differential equations are made by replacing the descriptions, applying the dependencies to the variables, integration over cells and differentiating the final system regarding to variables. Then, these differential equations complete the Galerkin matrix. As the solidification is a time-dependent process, an implicit backward method is employed for time integration and solving the system. Moreover, in this simulation an adaptive grid refinement strategy is used to refine the grid when the variable alterations are considerable. The refinement procedure continues during the process until the required precision which is determined by the user is obtained.
Moreover, a comparison between present numerical results and previous investigation [34] is done to approve the accuracy of this simulation, as depicted in Fig. 3. This figure compares the solidification fronts in the system at three time steps and indicates an excellent agreement between the results, so that the maximum reported error is equal to 4.9%.

sections.heading: 4.1. Optimization procedure of fin arrangement
sections.text:
This section focuses on the optimization of geometric parameters of V-shaped fin by employing RSM. The parameters which are selected to be optimized include the angle between fin branches (β), the fin length (L) and the fin thickness (w). The FST is set as the response of the optimization process which is required to be minimized.
Fig. 4 shows the influence of fin thickness on FST for three fin lengths. It can be seen that in all fin lengths, the change of FST is not considerable by augmenting the fin thickness and only a slight acceleration in solidification process is obtained. The reason of this slight acceleration is that increasing the fin thickness leads to augment the heat transfer area, while it does not increase the TPD into the PCM region and zone of fin impact. Consequently, the maximum fin thickness in the reviewed range is considered as its optimal value ( =w 1 mm).
The influence of fin length on the solidification acceleration is illustrated in Fig. 5. It can be seen that increasing the fin length expedites the solidification process significantly. Because, by augmenting the fin length, the TPD is enhanced to the PCM region which causes higher solidification rate. Moreover, due to the weak thermal conductivity of PCM, applying highly conductive fin in this region leads to a higher solidification rate. Consequently, the optimal fin length in the considered range is25mm.
Figs. 4 and 5 also demonstrate the influence of the fin branches
angle branches on solidification acceleration. It can be seen that for all fin lengths and thicknesses, by increasing this angle, first the FST drops and then increases. Because, in lower values of β, the V-shaped fin branches get closer to the axes and the PCM amount increases in the area between two fin branches in each quarter of the domain. Since the
V-shaped fin does not affect the TPD in this region, the solidification experiences lower rate which lead to increase the FST. Also, in higher values of β, the fin branches get closer to each other which causes the TPD to be enhanced in the area between two branches, while in the region between the fin branches and the axes, the solidification procedure is still slow. Therefore, the optimal value of β is expected to be between the minimum value ( = °β 11. 25 ) and maximum value ( = °β 45 ) of studied range. In current study, the optimal value ofβ is equal to °33. 75 which leads to the fastest solidification process. Based on the this analysis, = °β 33. 75 , =L 25 mm and =w 1 mm are considered as the best fin design from the sight of solidification acceleration. By considering this optimized fin arrangement in the triplex-tube LHTESS, the solidification is completed in 738.63 s.
Fig. 6 demonstrates the response surfaces of FST for several values of β, L and w. As mentioned before, it is obvious that the fin thickness does not change the FST considerably, while the branches angle and the fin length affect it remarkably. sections.heading: 4.2. Comparing the LHTESS performance in the presence of optimized Vshaped fin and without fin
sections.text:
When the PCM undergoes the phase change, the liberated thermal
energy is stored by the triplex-tube LHTESS. Despite the high storage capacity of PCM, their low thermal conductivity undermines the solidification process. Present study employs the V-shaped fin on the middle tube of the triplex-tube LHTESS to fix this defect. In order to demonstrate the benefit of such fin arrangement in the system, the solidification fronts of the LHTESS containing optimized V-shaped and without fin are compared in three various time steps, as depicted in Fig. 7. It can be seen that in the absence of fins, inception of
solidification is only at the neighborhood of cold walls, while attaching V-shaped fin to the middle tube of the triplex-tube LHTESS causes the TPD to be increased into the PCM region. Consequently, the solidification procedure starts near the cold walls and also in the vicinity of fin surface, which results in increasing the rate of heat transfer and expediting the process. It is noteworthy that the internal diameter of the LHTESS in the absence of fin is supposed to be greater than that of the LHTESS containing optimized fin, to satisfy the equality of PCM mass in
current comparison, as depicted in Fig. 7. Because, in the presence of Vshaped fin, less space is occupied by the PCM which reduces the PCM mass.
The contour plots of temperature and solid fraction for both LHTESS containing optimized V-shaped and without fin are illustrated in Figs. 8a and 8b, in three various time steps. This figure shows that using optimized V-shaped fin in the triplex-tube LHTESS causes more uniform temperature distribution as compared to the LHTESS without fin, which
leads to desired results in this study. In addition, as adding V-shaped fin enhances the TPD into the PCM region uniformly, the unsolidified PCM mass is reduced in the system. Consequently, the thermal resistance of the system decreases and the solidification procedure is completed faster than when no fin is employed in the system, as depicted in Fig. 8b.

sections.heading: 4.3. Dispersion of nanoparticle into the PCM
sections.text:
This section deals with the influence of dispersing nanoparticles into the PCM and making NEPCM. For this purpose, SWCNT nanoparticles with three different volume fractions equal to 0, 2.5, 5% are added to
the PCM. In order to demonstrate the impact of nanoparticles on the efficiency of triplex-tube LHTESS, Fig. 9 and Table 3 are presented. As shown in Table 3, making NEPCM in the LHTESS impressed the solidification process considerably. It is remarkable that the impact of nanoparticles is more considerable when the conduction mechanism predominates the process. As conduction is the main heat transfer mechanism which governs the solidification process, dispersing nanoparticles with higher volume fractions causes higher solid fraction. For example, a triplex-tube LHTESS containing nanoparticles with volume fraction equal to 5% expedites the process by about 33.1%, as tabulated in Table 3.
Fig. 9 illustrates the influence of nanoparticle volume fraction on the solidification front at three various time steps. As shown, at the inception of the process, using nanoparticles with higher volume fractions does not increase the solid fraction noticeably. However, as time progresses, increasing the volume fraction of nanoparticles causes a considerable augmentation to the solid fraction. Because, at the inception of process, only near cold wall regions which have a hightemperature variation with unsolidified PCM experience the solidification process. Accordingly, at the inception of the procedure, the solidification is expedited due to this high temperature difference and there is no need to enhancement approaches. But, as the time progresses, since ice with poor thermal conductivity is in the region between the cold walls and unsolidified PCM, the solidification procedure is weakened. Consequently, the thermal resistance of the system increases and the solidification procedure is done too slow which requires an enhancement approach to be accelerated.

sections.heading: 4.4. Comparison between the enhancement approaches
sections.text:
In this study, two enhancement approaches including the V-shaped fin and SWCNT nanoparticles are employed to quicken the solidification procedure in the triplex-tube LHTESS. Figs. 10 and 11 are displayed to compare these approaches from the sight of solidification rate and maximum capacity of energy storage. The average solid fraction for different cases during the process is depicted in Fig. 10. It should be notices that solidification rate is expressed as the slope of this figure. The triplex-tube LHTESS equipped with optimized fin experiences greater solidification rate than that of nanoparticle dispersion, which means that lower time is required for the solidification to be completed, as illustrated in Fig. 10. Results showed that the FST for the LHTESS containing optimized V-shaped fin is 1.94 times faster than that of the LHTESS without fin, and also 1.3 times faster than when SWCNT

The summation of sensible and latent heat is expressed as the total energy. As shown, the energy storage capacity experiences its maximum value at the inception of the process. Moreover, it is obvious that the maximum capacity of energy storage for all cases including the LHTESS without fin, LHTESS containing optimized fin and LHTESS with nanoparticles dispersion is approximately the same. However, the maximum solidification rate is obtained in the LHTESS containing optimized fin. Therefore, as the maximum solidification rate and also maximum capacity of energy storage are obtained in optimized Vshaped fin assisted LHTESS, attaching V-shaped fin to the triplex-tube LHTESS is reported as a more effective enhancement approach as compared to the nanoparticles dispersion.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
This study investigates the effect of V-shaped fin and also nanoparticles dispersion on the solidification procedure within a triplex-tube Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage System. By using response surface method, the geometric parameters of V-shaped fin are optimized to obtain the best fin arrangement. Minimizing the full solidification time is assumed as the objective function in the optimization procedure. In a separate analysis, SWCNT nanoparticles with various volume fractions are dispersed into the Phase Change Material to enhance its thermal conductivity and finally both enhancement approaches are compared. Numerical results illustrated that:
• Among the geometric parameters of V-shaped fin, fin length and branches angle significantly affect the solidification process, while the effect of fin thickness is not considerable. But, owing to a slight enhancement in heat transfer area, the highest fin thickness is reported as its optimal value in current investigation. • Augmenting the fin length increases the Thermal Penetration Depth into the region containing Phase Change Material and causes an accelerated phase change. Therefore, the highest fin length in the reviewed range is reported as its optimum value. • Since the solidification procedure is too slow in lower and higher values of β, the optimal value of β is between its maximum and minimum values in the reviewed range which is equal to °33. 75 . • Using SWCNT nanoparticles with the volume fraction of 2.5 and 5% accelerates the solidification procedure 1.16 and 1.49 times faster than when pure Phase Change Material is used in the system, respectively. • As the maximum solidification rate and also maximum capacity of energy storage is achieved by using optimized V-shaped fin, it is a more suitable approach, as compared to nanoparticle dispersion.

metadata.abstractText: This study deals with solidification expedition of Phase Change Material (PCM) in a triplex-tube Latent Heat Thermal Energy Storage System (LHTESS) by employing V-shaped fins and nanoparticles as enhancement approaches. The application of such systems is to balance the energy supply and requirement. Both approaches are used to compensate for the insignificant thermal conductivity of pure Phase Change Material and preventing the solidification process from weakening. In first enhancement approach, Response Surface Method (RSM) is used to optimize the geometric parameters of V-shaped fins to achieve best fin arrangement. The objective function of fin optimization is minimizing the Full Solidification Time (FST) to achieve the accelerated phase change process. In the second approach, SWCNT nanoparticles are dispersed to the water as Phase Change Material, and Nano-Enhanced Phase Change Material (NEPCM) is formed. Both approaches are performed separately and their results are compared. The simulation of solidification process is carried out utilizing Standard Galerkin Finite Element Method (SGFEM) along with adaptive grid refinement strategy. Results exhibited that using V-shaped fin in the system causes higher acceleration to the procedure, in comparison with nanoparticles dispersion.
